qas.question: What component gives glass the ability to conduct electricity?
How can glass be prevented from corroding?
What types of ions does typical glass have?
What can alkaline ions in glass harm, in addition to electrical resistance?
What component gives glass the ability to bridge oxygen atoms?
How can glass be prevented from diffusing?
What types of compunds does typical glass have?
Reaction with what causes oxygen ions to compensate for their charge?
What can alkaline ions in oxygen harm?

context: The <a0_0><b5_0>alkali metal ions<b5_0/><a0_0/> are small and mobile; their presence in glass allows a degree of electrical conductivity, especially in molten state or at high temperature. Their mobility decreases the chemical resistance of the glass, allowing leaching by water and facilitating corrosion. Alkaline earth ions, with their two positive charges and requirement for two non-bridging oxygen ions to compensate for their charge, are much less mobile themselves and also hinder diffusion of other ions, especially the alkalis. The most common commercial glasses contain both <a2_0><b7_0>alkali and alkaline earth ions<b7_0/><a2_0/> (usually sodium and calcium), for easier processing and satisfying corrosion resistance. Corrosion resistance of glass can be achieved by <a1_0><b6_0>dealkalization<b6_0/><a1_0/>, removal of the alkali ions from the glass surface by reaction with e.g. <a3_0><b8_0>sulfur or fluorine compounds<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Presence of alkaline metal ions has also detrimental effect to the <a4_0><b9_0>loss tangent<b9_0/><a4_0/> of the glass, and to its electrical resistance; glasses for electronics (sealing, vacuum tubes, lamps...) have to take this in account.
